roles.note: Some of the trees only include arg1 and arg2 under a single S node. Contrary to regular rules, it is ok in these cases to dig into the syntax and label arg1 and arg2 separately. Don't try to cram them into a single argument.

example.name: with attribute
example.text: Mary called John an idiot

example.name: passivized
example.text: The worksheets were called 'Learning Materials'

roleset.name: summon, perhaps to or by phone

example.name: without benefactive
example.text: The bells called the faithful to evensong

example.name: with benefactive
example.text: John called a doctor for Mary

example.name: benefactive with double NP
example.text: John called Mary a doctor.

example.name: reelection woes
example.text: Gore called for a recount.

example.name: without 'for'
example.text: Ford called a Jaguar stockholders' meeting.

example.name: it gets worse
example.text: ``You people here think this is Russian music,'' she said with disdain, and called over to the waitress: ``Could you turn it off?''

example.name: prognostication
example.text: His new forecast calls for a soft landing.

example.name: a better example
example.text: The weather forecast calls for light rain this morning.

role.descr: entity in charge, official decision maker

example.name: I'm in charge!
example.text: The changes were proposed in an effort to streamline federal bureaucracy and boost compliance by the executives ``who [*T*-1] are really calling the shots,'' said Brian Lane, special counsel at the SEC's office of disclosure policy, which proposed the changes.

example.name: call a game
example.text: Maybe it was the umpires who-1 [*-1] called the game in his favor.
example.note: In this usage, "calling the game" means deciding the outcome of the game, not shutting the game down. Obviously this kind of usage is where "call the shots" comes from.

example.name: Call the vote
example.text: Seconds before we call the vote to kick them out of power , the fire alarm goes off again .
example.arg: the vote to kick them out of power
example.note: In this interpretation, the officals are declaring the outcome of the vote.

roleset.name: call someone out on something (non-VPC version)

role.descr: accusation, thing called out (bluff, foul, bullshit, etc)

example.name: bring one's bluff to an end
example.text: Christie is being set up on this one and the legislature called his bluff

example.name: All args, oblique arg1
example.text: So what should I-1 do.. *PRO*-1 call him on his Bluff that he has an attorney that his whole family pitched in for and just file the papers how i want them
example.arg: on his Bluff that he has an attorney that his whole family pitched in for

example.name: All args, core arg 1. Call foul.
example.text: In golf ... you-1 got *PRO*-1 ta call fouls on yourself . And golfers do !

example.name: all args, call bullshit
example.text: The President of the executive body openly started threatening and intimidating people who-1 *trace*-1 were calling them on their bullshit .

roleset.note: Added by Julia based on BOLT.

roleset.name: claim (like dibs)

example.name: call shotgun
example.text: If you call shotgun, you get the privilege to sit in the passenger seat in front, next to the driver.

example.name: call dibs
example.text: Evan already called dibs on this guitar.

roleset.note: Added by Julia in tandem with call.13, based on BOLT.

predicate.note: sFrames file for 'call' based on Chris' old frames file; this is still a mess and inconsistent with most of the other verbs. It will have to be revised and the tagging redone before the next iteration.

example.name: without benefactive
example.text: The bells called up the faithful to evensong

example.name: with benefactive
example.text: John called up a doctor for Mary

example.name: is that so?
example.text: EC Agriculture Commissioner Ray MacSharry said the U.S. plan ``calls into question'' the agreement reached by world negotiators last April in Geneva seeking ``substantial progressive reductions in agricultural support and protection.''
example.arg: the agreement reached by world negotiators last April in Geneva seeking ``substantial progressive reductions in agricultural support and protection.''

predicate.note: This really is phrasal. Otherwise identical to the 'summon' roleset

example.name: with benefactive
example.text: John called in a doctor for Mary

predicate.note: This is phrasal, otherwise identical to 'summon' roleset.

example.name: with benefactive
example.text: John called on a doctor.

example.name: with secondary predication
example.text: Rep. Neal's bill originally called on the Fed [*-1] to reduce the inflation rate by one percentage point a year for five years and to maintain a zero inflation rate thereafter.
example.arg: [*-1] to reduce the inflation rate by one percentage point a year for five years and to maintain a zero inflation rate thereafter.

example.name: call off talks
example.text: Boeing Co., already struck by its Machinists union, briefly called off contract talks with its engineers and labeled their demands ``grossly excessive.''
example.arg: Boeing Co., already struck by its Machinists union

role.descr: purpose of arg1, called upon to do what?

example.name: Passive
example.text: However , he never imagined that the role whnp-1 he-2 was called upon *-2 *PRO* to play *t*-1 would be so lonely and dismal .
example.note: Relative clause trace is embedded in arg2, thus Link-SLC is not annotated.

roleset.name: call someone out on something (VPC version)

role.descr: accusation, what arg2 is called out on

example.name: Args 0, 1
example.text: Often these people would decry the " PC liberal media " for *PRO* not calling it out . (
example.note: (In the larger context, it was clear that 'it' referred to a behavior, which fits under arg1.)

roleset.note: Added by Julia based on BOLT. No VNcls. Corresponds to call-v.13
